For Release Tuesday AMs, Dec. 26, and thereafter
Non-Communist Cambodian Guerrillas Face Erosion of Western Support
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's non-communist guerrillas are seeing an erosion of support from the Western world at a time when they are making significant gains against the Vietnamese-backed government in Cambodia. ``Everywhere in the world the communist system is falling,'' said Gen. Sak Sutsakarn, commander-in-chief of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. ``Why won't the world support the non-communists in Cambodia? Especially Cambodia _ we have suffered more than anyone.'' The apparent reason for the diminishing support is a concern that the non-communists are coordinating their military offensive with the communist Khmer Rouge, which took power in 1976 and inflicted a reign of terror on Cambodia that left a million or more dead. The National Liberation Front, the Khmer Rouge and a non-communist group loyal to Prince Nordom Sihanouk, the former head of state, have formed a loose alliance that has been waging war against the Vietnamese and the Cambodian government they installed in Phnom Penh, the capital, in 1979. The coalition, which holds Cambodia's seat in the United Nations, is largely armed by China, but the two non-communist factions get U.S. and other Western financial and political support. The non-communists still reel from charges of corruption, internal bickering and being militarily inneffectual. But they have established better internal discipline over the past two years and, in recent months, they have shown battlefield prowess. In recent weeks, a number of U.S. congressmen have criticized Washington's support for the non-communists as tantamount to support for the Khmer Rouge. Britain backed away from supporting the non-communists in November following media reports that the British were training soldiers ``under the control of Pol Pot,'' the shadowy Khmer Rouge leader who led Cambodia's terror government until a Vietnamese ousted him in 1979 after they invaded the country. Australia and France have voiced support for leaving Cambodia's U.N. seat vacant, creating more cracks in what only months ago was a solid Western bloc of support for the coalition. All three groups seek either the downfall of the government of leader Hun Sen in Phnom Penh or leverage at the negotiating table, but reporters able to reach battle zones or newly taken towns have seen no sign of joint military operations between the non-communists and the Khmer Rouge. With the bodies of government soldiers lying in nearby trenches, National Liberation Front guerrillas celebrated their biggest victory of the war recently with the capture of Svay Chek, a key town. ``Where are the Khmer Rouge?'' said Gen. Khun Roeng pointing toward hundreds of his guerrillas on the defense perimeter. ``The Khmer Rouge are not invited to this party.'' Resistance leaders acknowledge, however, that they do have field communication with the Khmer Rouge but solely for reasons of not getting in the way of each other's attacks. The non-communists have seized more than 100 square miles of territory in northwest Cambodia since launching a general offensive after Vietnam began withdrawing its last troops from Cambodia in September. ``We have two enemies,'' says Gen. Dien Del, the National Liberation Front's founder. ``The first is the Vietnamese and then the Khmer Rouge. The Cambodian people understand that Vietnam wants to swallow our country, and that is why all patriots have a duty to work together to save Cambodia. But we are not with the Khmer Rouge, and the Khmer Rouge knows this very well.'' He added: ``We need the public support of the Americans. ... We need to be able to say, `Look, we are backed by the West.''' Sak, the commander-in-chief, said: ``What happens to Cambodia if support for the non-communist resistance stops? The war will continue between the two communists _ the Khmer Rouge and the Hun Sen government. There will be no peace, but it guarantees the future government will be a communist one.''
